text: but I haven’t used it so I can’t tell you whether it works well with the drawer or not :slightly_smiling_face:
but in general: a fragment is a view with back stack built in. If you manage that back stack yourself you can replace fragments with views easy peasy.

What I dislike about those frameworks is that most of the time they solve a very specific problem/use case the creator had but are hard once you get to that edge case in your app where you either resort to some shitty workaround or spend hours and hours figuring out a proper solution/fork the framework
thanks for the interest guys
Pretty sure you can ask 10 people and get 30 opinions on this topic :wink:
let me ask you this, regarding the inheritance implementation - wouldn't that be essentially code duplication?
first. and second, wouldn't that be severely high coupling? what if tomorrow I'd want to use the same activity with a different navigation method
isn’t anything navigation related high coupling by definition?
unless you take the bus approach and you’re quickly at the other extreme

true that. I'm being a nuisance with this one because my application is a bit more dynamic than usual... for instance, the same activity could be used either with a Tabs navigation or with a Drawer navigation
hence the difficulty
inheritance tends to be ok… until you’ve got levels upon levels of it.

Well our BaseHomeActivity holds nothing but the drawer and overrides setContentView so that it inflates the implementing Activity’s layout into its root container. Not pretty probably but it works. For Activitys without navigation we have another base class
yeah same here
we actually have something like a YourSpecificActivity -> DrawerActivity / ModalActivity -> BaseActivity
but it’s becoming unweildy
there’s always some duplication
But agree, we have some mad inheritance there too with some more specific Activitys like BaseSinglePaneActivity and BaseMultipaneActivity for single/multi fragment layouts respectively
even if you take pure delegation approach you’ll need to relay the events to delegates everywhere thus duplicating code :slightly_smiling_face:
haha true
it’s all a rule of thumb
sure seems odd that there's no best practice to it... thought it's just me
well no app is the same
I mean, my partner does the same app in iOS. and they have the whole Controller approach which takes pretty good care ofit
once you get to specifics you’ll need to start going custom
a similar implementation in Android would ignore the activity lifecycles though, I think...
yeah sometimes that’s just the best thing to do.
handle lifecycle changes manually, write a bunch of Helper/Manager classes that do that and use them everywhere
framework is there for you… until it becomes a burden :slightly_smiling_face:
damn, that's my greatest fear :slightly_smiling_face:
doing something that seems right, but then having to manage things manually therefore causing more problems 3 months from now
writing code that’s unreadable and un-understandable to anyone but you is a surefire way to not get fired 3 months in a row :joy: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
anyhow many thanks for the healthy discussion <@U053PPGDC>, <@U04TK850N>... it's comforting to know that there's no one great solution, in a way :slightly_smiling_face:
hahaha
no prob
what if that's my own company? :smile:
steve jobs was fired from his own company :joy:
Even better! :smile:
lol
haha
giving the best of job security advices <@U053PPGDC>: :taco:
:joy:

<@U0UETGCJU>: I have a drawer activity and use fragments per screen. I haven't really come across lifecycle problems. I believe that as long as you code cleanly then you won't run into NPEs and such. By using Dagger 2 and MVP on the Presentation side I have never run into NPEs from fragments
basically my presenter never calls a view method from the fragment unless the fragment absolutely exists
^ I usually do this to
Basically the Android equivalent of single page web apps
the kind of minor annoyance was deciding who should hold the management of the toolbar, but that depends a lot on the app

Always keep in mind this, start simple and then reiterate. Code is like a book, you write the draft and then you iterate over it again and again. Do not cloud your mind with every possible outcome at once
Or be a college student and goof off until the last minute then do everything in 1 marathon session

<@U09T8SFG8>, I'm torn here. on the one hand I'd like to avoid the usual drawer implementation of code duplication (or smarter inheritance), but on the other, with the fragments implementation I deem myself not knowledgeable enough to foresee the problems that might be caused by the OS or some other unknowns down the road, and then having to change the architecture all over again due to bad philosophy...
<@U0UETGCJU>: If you haven’t tried this before, 100% chance your first attempt will suck
:smile:
but if you don’t try it out, 100% chance you will learn nothing
do your best, make mistakes
all part of gaining experience

definitely. I'd usually dive right into it as well. however I'm on a tight schedule and need to consult the higher wisdom of the masses to avoid mistakes as much as possible, at least the huge pitfalls :slightly_smiling_face:
>Do not cloud your mind with every possible outcome at once - :thumbsup::skin-tone-4:
(and you've all been highly effective in that regard, hehe)
> but if you don’t try it out, 100% chance you will learn nothing
as the great philosopher Gretzky once said, you miss 100% of the shots you don’t take.

basically no decision is final
treat them as learning opportunities
Pretty much how it goes
every fuckup can be reversed

<@U0UETGCJU>: since you have not really used fragments in this setting before, definitely go the fragment way. Fragments are a must to know for every android developer and the other options you can have (eventbus, custom views etc.) will definitely be more complicated by the end of it because of your inexperience with fragments in this setting.

anyone familiar with wallpaper scrolling issue on android?
it’s not so much an issue as it is something that is left to each implementation of a launcher to properly implement or choose to support at all
aka launchers are sometimes bad and there isn’t anything you can do about it
well, I have developed an app that uses wallpaperManager, so I would like to avoid instructing users to use launchers as part of my solution that I provide
my goal is to have non scrolling wallpaper, but no luck with some of the devices (no idea why)
because again you are at the mercy of launchers to be implemented properly
well I dont see the docs for it so it may be the system implementation that controls it which would make sense from the IPC standpoint.
But regardless its the same conclusion. You are completely at the mercy of something out of your control to do what you want.
do you know if scrolling was disabled by default since KitKat? (when you provide exact screen pixels)?
works fine on my nexus devices
so probably it is not Android version problem, but rather what launcher is being used by the user

attachments.title: Stacktraces and subscribeOn/observeOn · Issue #3521 · ReactiveX/RxJava · GitHub
attachments.text: RxJava in not nice when it comes to stacktraces. The worst thing is observeOn that schedules execution on different threads. Every time we use observeOn we get our stacktrace from the process roo...

I’m trying to come up with a regex pattern that can search a string for instances of “<%blah8 hello%>” where the start of the match would be “<%” and the end would be “%>”, the matcher would give me “blah8 hello” — that’s just a sample text, it really could be just about any letter + number combo

So using the expression on this string 
```
Hello <%FirstName%>. Todays date is <%Date%> and the current time is <%Time%>. I see you are from <%State%>, that your phone number is <%PhoneNumber%> and that you like <%Survey.Favorite Food%>!
```
 I’d be able to pull out “Date”, “Time”, “State”, “PhoneNumber”, and “Survey.Favorite Food"
